#lisajewell #books #fall #thrillerbooks #reading #fallaesthetic #invisiblegirlbook #bookstagram #bookstagrammer

Rating: 3.5 ğŸ“š

Invisible Girl follows Cate, Saffyre, and Owen as their lives become entangled through mysterious assaults happening within a neighborhood in London. There's not much I can say without revealing spoilers, but it is a book that deals with sexual assault, domestic violence, incels, revenge, self-harm, and predatory behavior. The book is more of a psychological mystery, and the multi-perspective plot leaves readers guessing until the very end, breaking down our own stereotypical views of characters. Essentially, Lisa Jewell provides many open avenues, creating a story more complex than a simple "whodunnit?"

â„ï¸â„ï¸â„ï¸â„ï¸â„ï¸â„ï¸â„ï¸â„ï¸â„ï¸â„ï¸â„ï¸â„ï¸â„ï¸â„ï¸

I can't say I enjoyed Invisible Girl because it does deal with difficult content, but I will say it's a valuable book. Jewell writes developed characters whose motivations are emotional, driven, and aptly reflect their circumstances. It's also the first book I've read with mention of incels, which brought an added layer of relevancy regarding problematic and vile views toward women. On the other hand, there are so many characters that the story can feel flat at times. As soon as I started becoming entrenched in one character's experiences, I was thrown into another, which stilted my momentum.

Recommendation: Yes!

Invisible Girl By Lisa Jewell 

Saffyre Maddox disappeared on the night of Valentineâ€™s Day and the last person who saw her was Owen, whoâ€™s in his thirties and living in his aunts spare bedroom and has just been suspended from his job as a geography teacher for sexual misconductâ€¦ 
Across the street is the perfect family of the Fours, funnily enough Roan was Saffyreâ€™s psychologist for years. 
All very close to homeâ€¦ 
I flew through this book as it kept me guessing to the end. 
Another brilliant thriller from Lisa Jewell ğŸ“š

 #bookstagram #booklover #bookstagrammer #bookaddict #booktecommendations #bookreview #booksofinstagram #bookchallenge #reading #readingbooks #readingchallenge #readingcommunity #invisiblegirl #invisiblegirlbook #lisajewell #lisajewellauthor

ğŸ“šRead That

Invisible Girl

Iâ€™m a big Lisa Jewell fan so I was thrilled to receive an ARC copy from @atriabooks in exchange for an honest review! This one is also my second read for @readwithangie #thrilleroctoberv2

The young Saffyre Maddox spent three years as a patient of psychologist Roan Fours. After feeling abandoned by him, she starts following him and observing him in his neighbourhood. When Saffyre goes missing, Owen, a creepy, lonely young man across the street from the Fours house is the last one to see her alive. The Fours, Owen and Saffyre stories start to intertwine and culminate on the night Saffyre went missing.. Valentineâ€™s Day.

This gives us all the â€œwho can you trust?â€ Vibes of a domestic thriller! Lisa Jewell is a master of spinning a lot of characters stories that weave together to intricately it makes for a quick, addicting read! Owen particularly is a bizarre  character and his life on incel websites is hard to read about and yet you canâ€™t put the book down!

This was one of the more thought provoking thrillers Iâ€™ve read in a while. Invisible Girl is a psychological thriller that has great emphasis on the psychological part! We see human nature, prejudice, and how our past effected our present and future in this story. Thank you to @pupsplantsandplotlines for discussing this one with me!

Invisible Girl pub day is today so if your a Lisa Jewell fan like me, go grab it!

âœ¨THOUGHTSâœ¨ 

I was extremely frustrated about someone innocent being made to look guilty. It was so hard to read because I kept thinking how unfair it was ğŸ˜©ğŸ˜‚ I wanted to jump through the book and scream â€œHE DIDNT DO ITâ€. Although that doesnâ€™t mean he was entirely innocent eitherâ€¦ 

I really liked Saffyreâ€™s character and her actions are completely justified. Thatâ€™s all. The end. 

This book touched on rape, and women being groped and touched. It was disturbing to read about, and even more so because this is something that happens everyday. As women we are stripped of the right to our personal space because men think they are entitled to everything, even our bodies. 

Overall I enjoyed the book, I liked that it showcased different stories and the absurd way they all came together in the end!

This book was a slower read for me. I found it similar in writing style as Local Missing Woman, in the sense that it was told from multiple perspectives. This one wasnâ€™t told from different tenses which was nice. There were multiple stories that came together as the book progressed, which was really intriguing. Youâ€™d think in a normal world these characters wouldnâ€™t ever interact and yet in a twisted way, they did. 

As with previous thrillers, I was intrigued to read about what exactly happened and how the book would end!! 

Have you read this book??

I finally  got round to reading ğŸ“š invisible girl which is a slow burner psychological thriller. 
 
The story revolves around Owen a reclusive teacher who has no luck with women and lives with his aunt who reluctantly  let's him stay there and only on her terms.
 
Next is saffyre a troubled teenager who lives with her uncle and has a traumatic  past ,she has also been receiving help from roan fours a child phsycologst who lives across the road from Owen with his wife and teenage children.

A number of attacks against  women have been happening  in the area and when saffyre disappears Owen is under suspicion  after 2 school girls make allegations about him . 
Is he  misunderstood,  a victim because of his social awkwardness or is he a wolf in sheep's  clothing. 
The story is told by many pov,which helps understand the characters.  It is slow at the start but picks up.  Not a bad read. #invisiblegirlbook#lisajewellinvisiblegirl

â˜ï¸Invisible girl ~ Lisa Jewell â˜ï¸ 4/5 â­ï¸ 
On the back:
Midnight: in an area of urban wasteland where cars hunt & foxes shriek, a girl is watchingâ€¦
When Saffyre Maddox was ten, something terrible happened and sheâ€™s carried the pain of it ever since. The man she thought was going to heal her didnâ€™t, and now she hides learning his secrets, invisible in the shadows. 
Owen pick is invisible too. Heâ€™s never had a girlfriend; heâ€™s never even had a friend. Nobody see him. Nobody cares. 
But when Saffyre goes missing from opposite his house on Valentineâ€™s night, suddenly the world seems to be watching Owen. Accusing him. Holding him responsible for Saffyres disappearanceâ€¦

My review:
I really enjoyed this book, being a fan anyways of Lisa Jewells work I expected to like it. I thought the twists were quite good and somewhat unexpected. I was kept guessing the whole time as to â€˜who dun itâ€™! The life lessons in the storyline of the respect for women was a great addition too on such an intense plot.
Overall I gave this a star 4/5 â­ï¸ rating

Book Review - Invisible Girl 
â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸/ 5 
Whenever you read a Lisa Jewell book you know itâ€™s going to be an interesting mystery. It took me a bit of time the first couple of chapters to wrap my head around the different characters as each chapter is from a one of the 3 main characters perspective; Cate, Saffyre and Owen and because of that I found it a bit of a slow paced book.
When the plot starts to come together towards the end of the book it turns a lot more fast paced and I found I didnâ€™t want to put the book down because I wanted to know what happened
If you love Lisa Jewellâ€™s books already youâ€™re going to like this, but if I could only pick one she has better books than this one

"Invisible Girl" by Lisa Jewell

ğŸ“£My review-- Invisible Girl is told in the point of view of three of the characters; Cate, Owen and Saffyre. The different points of views immersed me further into the story as we tried to solve what happened to Saffyre. The story was told in a before the night and after the night which gave some great lead up.  I had no idea the whole way through the story how it was going to play out.

YES SO GOOD MY FAVOURITE SO FAR OF HER BOOKS.

I honestly canâ€™t say thereâ€™s a loose end that wasnâ€™t tied up that I can think of? I read it all in one sitting because not a single part of it bored me i was very intrigued the whole book. Iâ€™ve heard people dislike it because they disliked the characters but I liked everyone and how developed so many were without confusion.

I would say more thriller than mystery but man I enjoyed the development of all the characters, the only thing was that at the start I thought it might keep going between different characters the whole time and I wouldnâ€™t be able to follow but it didnâ€™t happen the 3 perspectives were good! 

Also there was this weird thing about one of the characters purposely flicking sweat from his head onto people multiple times and Iâ€™m still so confused ğŸ˜‚ I just donâ€™t understand the flicking of the sweat onto people at all.

But overall great mystery/thriller, really enjoyed as a light read.

INVISIBLE GIRL - LISA JEWELL 4/5 â­ï¸

INVISIBLE GIRL tells the tale of a young girl, trying desperately to cope with her childhood traumas, when she goes missing... A man who is not who he claims to be... And a family caught in the drama between the two. The lives of all connected to the disappearance will forever be changed in this psychological drama. 

Cate, married to Roan, is a blissfully ignorant wife and mother to two children. 

Saffyre, a young teen, tries to come to terms with the storm inside her head while still playing the role of a sweet niece and studious, popular girl. 

Owen, a typical â€œcreepyâ€ guy, gets his life turned on its side multiple times throughout the book, who is very unaware of himself and his surroundings in shocking ways. 

The narration of the book alternates between the three of these characters. From there, the reader gets a firsthand glimpse into the terror, misunderstandings, heartbreak, and anxiety that comes along with each one. 

INVISIBLE GIRL was such an interesting book- it was devoured in less than a day for me! I found each of the characters fascinating in their own way, but I think I enjoyed viewing the story through Cate the most. Lisa Jewell truly has a gift when it comes to building characters, and this book is a perfect example. The one issue I had was that I wasnâ€™t completely sold on Owenâ€™s seemingly overnight change, but who knows! It most definitely didnâ€™t take anything away from the story, and it was a very enjoyable read. Look forward to not leaving your couch from the time you crack this one open, until you read the final pages! ğŸ˜

ğˆğ§ğ¯ğ¢ğ¬ğ¢ğ›ğ¥ğ ğ†ğ¢ğ«ğ¥ by Lisa Jewell @bookofthemonth selection â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸â£
â£
When teenage girl Saffyre goes missing, the community looks at awkward longer Owen who has recently been accused of sexual assault. â£
â£
After some hemming and hawing about getting this book or not, I added it in November. I wasnâ€™t a huge fan of the Family Upstairs. I ended up loving this! Okay, the incel community has always fascinated me, in a totally disturbing way. I got an up close view with this story, and it was just as cringey and shiver inducing as I thought. However, Lisa Jewell did a great job of presenting a character who was sympathetic and worthy of redemption. Thatâ€™s only a small portion for the story. A major theme in the book is sexual assault, so readers should be aware. It does include a graphic telling of an episode that could be trigger inducing. There was some back and forth but it was not confusing at all. There were several characters who could have potentially been the â€œbad guyâ€, and it was a lot of fun to watch it play out. The end was pretty shocking, even thought not entirely unexpected. â£
â£

Letâ€™s kick off this #winterbook party with these thrillers, shall we? â„ï¸ 

Set in the French Alps, a luxe Scottish hunting lodge, and posh London, these three books transported me to gorgeous snowy locations and kept me guessing until the end. Thrillers always offer a bit of an escape, but the winter wonderland settings of these was salve for my travel starved heart! 

Break out your coziest blanket, pour some bourbon, and crack open one of these novels next to a fireplace. You will be in a #winterwonderland before you know it.

Invisible Girl by Lisa Jewell

My first Lisa Jewell book. It was fine. I usually judge audiobooks harsher than physical books. I am a bit picky when it comes to the voices and acting. But honestly, I could listen Donna Banya read the phone book... her voice was so raw and honest. It made Sapphireâ€™s chapters live and breathe. 

But in all, I just didnâ€™t see it as a thriller. Maybe psychological suspense. I felt I was strung along a bit when you realize every single POV is unreliable. And I usually enjoy the use of flashback, but this was just a bit confusing.

Ive already started another of her books, so weâ€™ll see if I end up liking the authorâ€™s style a bit more.

Also looking forward to trying out this new red blend thatâ€™s new to the menu. Arenâ€™t these Gemme Vineyard bottles gorgeous?
